title-group.article-title: Modeling and control of an electronic wedge brake

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Automotive Engineering, Hanyang University, Seoul, Korea

abstract.p: The electronic wedge brake is one of the brake-by-wire systems with a self-energizing effect. It is attractive because it can produce enough braking torque with the 12-voltage system. However, the electronic wedge brake cannot be implemented unless the self-energizing effect is effectively controlled. In this study, the electronic wedge brake is modeled into dynamic equations, and a sliding mode controller is designed based on the model. The clamping force is estimated based on the simplified electronic wedge brake model and the contact point detection algorithm is also provided. The performance of the proposed controller is verified in simulations and experiments using a prototype electronic wedge brake.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In future automobiles, conventional hydraulic brake systems can be replaced by electrically operated brake systems called brake-by-wire (BBW). The BBW system is easier to pack because flexible wires can be used and is less complicated to provide faster braking actuation. It can be used not only for the enhanced safety braking of the intelligent vehicle, but also for the environmentally friendly vehicles, e.g. the hybrid electric vehicle and the electric vehicle, in order to save dissipated energy with optimal capability. The stability functions such as anti-lock braking system, traction control system, and electronic stability control can be easily implemented without additional mechanical or hydraulic components.

Among the BBW, the electronic wedge brake (EWB) was introduced to generate the brake force by controlling the electronic actuator and self-energizing wedge mechanisms. The EWB does not need a vacuum booster and master cylinder, which makes it simple in the engine room configuration. The electronic actuator includes motor, servo controller, electronic control unit, communication interface, and current and position sensors. The EWB should be designed into a component unit because it is attached to the rotor wheel.

The EWBs with the current 12-voltage system have been introduced by several manufacturers.1–7 Modeling and control of EWB was investigated by Fox et al.8 where a new type of EWB with one motor is developed. Simulation and experimental results are shown using two different control approaches; the first control approach is based on a cascade controller and the other one the state-feedback to generate almost identical step responses for a broad range of parameter variation. Streli et al.9 and Balogh et al.10 developed a mechanical model including the friction characteristics and designed a controller for the EWB. A nonlinear model is presented including the accurate description of the friction characteristics in the self-amplifying brake and the contact between the brake pad and the disc. Since the wedge mechanism has nonlinear vibrations and instability, a sliding mode controller is used to avoid the presence of unstable periodic motions or states. Based on the relationship between torque and position information, contact point detection and push–pull control of the actuator were studied to prevent jamming of the EWB system (Jo et al.11,12).

In this study, modeling of the EWB is developed for the motor, worm gear/wheel, power screw/nut, caliper, and wedge. The developed model is compared with a three-dimensional (3-D) multi-body dynamics (MBD) simulation tool and also validated with the experimental results. The clamping force estimation method is proposed based on a simplified EWB model. A sliding model controller with the estimated clamping force is designed to apply the desired clamping force in braking. For prompt braking action, contact point detection algorithms are also proposed. The performance of the proposed control algorithm is verified in simulations and experiments using a prototype EWB test bench.

sec.title: Modeling of the EWB
sec.p:
This section introduces the modeling of the EWB which includes permanent magnet synchronous motor (PMSM), worm gear/wheel, power screw/nut, caliper, and wedge. Figure 1 shows the overall structure of the EWB. Figure 1.
Model of the EWB.

sec.title: Modeling of the PMSM
sec.p: The widely used PMSM is adopted in the EWB.13 The voltage equations of a PMSM can be expressed in time varying differential equations where three phases of a, b, and c frames are transformed into d, q, and n frames by the reference frame transformation. First, the electrical part of the PMSM can be expressed in the rotor reference frame.14,15

Second, the mechanical part of the PMSM can be modeled as follows (1)ddtωM=1JMeq(TM-BMeqωM-TLeq) where ωM, JMeq, TM, BMeq, and TLeq are motor angular speed, equivalent moment of inertia, electric torque, equivalent damping coefficient, and equivalent load torque at the motor shaft, respectively. The electric torque, TM, can be simplified to a separately excited DC motor where id is forced to zero by the vector control of the PMSM. (2)TM=3PλPMiq2≡kTiq where P, λPM, iq, and kT are the number of pole pairs, flux linkage due to the rotor magnets linking the stator, q-axis stator current, and torque constant. The torque equation is similar to that of a separately excited DC motor. Since the magnetic flux linkage is constant, the torque is directly proportional to the q-axis current.

sec.title: Modeling of the worm gear/wheel and the power screw/nut
sec.p: In equation (1), the inertias of the worm gear/wheel and the power screw/nut are included in JMeq. (3)JMeq=Jr+Jwg+[Jww+Jps+mpn(Pps2π)2]1ng where Jr is the moment of inertia of the rotor and shaft, Jwg the moment of inertia of the worm gear, Jww the moment of inertia of the worm wheel, Jps the moment of inertia of the power screw and shaft, mpn the mass of the power screw nut, Pps the pitch of the power screw, and ng the gear ratio. The following equation represents the gear ratio. (4)1ng=ωscrewωM

The equivalent damping coefficient at the motor shaft is expressed as (5)BMeq=BM+Bps1ng where BM is the damping coefficient of the rotor and worm gear shaft and Bps the damping coefficient of the worm wheel and power screw. The equivalent load torque in equation (1) can be written as (6)TLeq=Pps2πηps1ngFps where Fps is the force acting on the wedge from the power screw and ηps the torque/force efficiency.

sec.title: Modeling of the caliper and wedge
sec.p: The configuration of the wedge brake is illustrated in Figure 1. It is assumed that μwedge is very small and negligible because the low-friction coating is usually applied on the wedge surface. The behavior of the wedge is governed by the following equations (7)mwddtvw=Fps+μFN-sinθwFwedge (8)mwtanθwddtvw=-FN+cosθwFwedge where θw is the wedge angle, mw the mass of the wedge, vw the velocity of the wedge in xw-direction, μ the friction coefficient between the pad and the disc, FN the clamping force between the pad and the disc, and Fwedge the normal force to the wedge edge, respectively.
Equations (7) and (8) are combined as follows (9)mw(1+tan2θw)ddtvw=Fps+(μ-tanθw)FN

The clamping force between the pad and the disc can be expressed as (10)FN=kcaltanθwxw where kcal is the caliper stiffness. Because the contact between the power screw nut and the wedge has a much higher stiffness than the caliper structure, the dynamics of the contact can be neglected for the purpose of controller design. The position and velocity of the EWB can be calculated using the following equations (11)xw=xpn=Pps2π1ngθM (12)vw=vpn=Pps2π1ngωM where xw and xpn are the positions of the wedge and the power screw nut in the xw-direction, respectively, and vpn the velocity of the power screw nut in the xw-direction. Because the change in the wedge velocity is very small, the force acting on the wedge from the power screw is simplified from equations (9) to (11). (13)Fps=(tanθw-μ)FN =(tanθw-μ)kcaltanθwPps2π1ngθM

sec.title: Control algorithm design of the EWB
sec.p: This section presents the control algorithm design for the EWB. The proposed clamping force controller can be used either as an economic solution without using expensive force sensors or as a fail-safe control strategy in case of the force sensor failure. For the service braking operation, the clamping force controller should be able to detect the air gap and the contact point.

sec.title: Clamping force controller design
sec.p: For the robustness against parameter variations and various nonlinearities in the EWB, sliding mode control strategy is applied in this study for designing the clamping force controller. sec.title: Contact point detection and air gap determination
sec.p: The air gap between the pad and the disc is normally an unknown parameter. The air gap should be properly maintained after braking to avoid residual brake torque, reduce pad wear and energy waste at each wheel, and be ready for rapid braking. If the motor torque can be obtained in the EWB, the relationship between the motor torque and the rotor position can be utilized for detecting the contact point.11 In this study, the contact point through the forward or backward braking contact is detected based on the motor speed change during the initializing operations. The predetermined current command, icpd, is applied to the motor in the forward braking direction. The initial forward contacting point, θcpd_f, can be detected based on the motor angular position when the angular speed of the motor begins to decrease. The initial backward contacting point, θcpd_b, can also be determined in the same manner. After several repeated procedures, the average contacting points, θcpd_f_avg and θcpd_b_avg, can be calculated. Using these values and the predetermined air gap, lairgap, the angular position command of the motor, θ* M, can be determined as follows (33)θM *=θcpd_f_avg-2πPpsng1tanθwlairgap (in> >forward> >braking) and (34)θM *=θcpd_b_avg+2πPpsng1tanθwlairgap (in> >backward> >braking).

sec.title: Control structure
sec.p:
Because of nonlinear environment and parameter variation, the individual wheel should be operated separately based on position, current, and clamping force information. sec.title: Model validation
sec.p:
The 3-D simulation tool of EWB is constructed as shown in Figure 4 using RecurDyn which is an MBD software.17,18 The EWB model in ‘Modeling of the EWB’ section and the 3-D simulation tool are validated with experimental results. For the experimental results, the test bench is built with a prototype EWB. Table 1 presents the parameters used in the simulation and experiments. The clamping forces from the EWB model, the simulation tool, and the experimental prototype are compared in Figure 5 with different clamping force commands. The transient response of the model is very close to the experimental results for the given test. Figure 4.

sec.title: Controller validation
sec.p:
The performance of the proposed clamping force controller is verified using the simulation model and compared with a standard proportional–integral (PI) cascade controller. The control algorithm is implemented using the MATLAB software.19 The power screw is one of the major sources of nonlinearities in the EWB system and its characteristics can be approximated by a look-up table based on the experimental data. For example, the power screw efficiency variation is shown in Figure 6 where its minimum and maximum boundaries are approximately within 4% of the nominal value. The sliding mode controller is compared with a tuned PI controller for various conditions and a step response of the EWB system is illustrated in Figure 7. Figures 8 and 9 compare the PI cascaded and the sliding mode controllers utilizing the estimated clamping force. Figures 10 and 11 compare the two controllers based on the measured clamping force signal. In both cases, the sliding mode controller shows better performance than the PI controller. In particular, Figure 9 demonstrates the feasibility of the sliding mode control strategy based on the estimated clamping force. Figure 6.

sec.title: Experiment
sec.p:
For experimental verification, the hardware-in-the loop simulation (HILS) test bench is constructed, as shown in Figure 12, including a prototype EWB. In Figure 13, the ‘•’ marks near 0.55 s represent the detected contact point where the rotor acceleration drops below a threshold. The actual contact point occurs at 0.52 s where the clamping force starts to develop. The position error in detecting the contact point can be determined based on the detection time error, rotor speed, and screw pitch. For instance, the detection error in this study is approximately 0.4 mm. Figure 12.
Experimental set-up of the EWB test bench. Figure 13.
Contact point detection result.

As suggested in the ‘Controller validation’ section, control performance based on the estimated clamping force is validated for various braking commands. Figure 14 shows the response of the EWB system to a step command. When the brake pedal is pressed in the HILS system, 0.1 s delay can be observed, whereas when releasing the brake pedal, 0.2 s delay can be seen. The time delay in braking is mainly due to the structures of the EWB prototype and can be reduced by the design change. The time delay in releasing is caused by the residual stress of a prototype load-cell sensor when clamping force is suddenly released. Figures 15 and 16 show the experimental results of the clamping force control with a series of pressing the braking pedal in the HILS. Figures 17 and 18 show the zoom-in images of Figures 15 and 16, respectively. As shown in the figures, the command curve represents the driver’s intention and is generated based on the pedal displacement. The sliding model controller updates the motor current to follow the command and the tracking error in the clamping force is calculated utilizing the estimated clamping force. The experimental results demonstrate that the proposed controller based on the estimated clamping force generates the clamping force effectively and accurately. Figure 14.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The model of the EWB is developed including the PMSM, the worm gear/wheel, the power screw/nut, the caliper, and the wedge. The developed model is simplified by considering the operating conditions of the EWB in order to design the proper control algorithms. The EWB model is validated with a 3-D MBD simulation tool and the experimental set-up. Two types of the control structure, one using the estimated clamping force and the other the measured clamping force, are investigated for the clamping force control. The sliding mode control algorithm is applied for the EWB with the contact point detection algorithm. The simple PI cascade control and the proposed algorithms are compared in simulations. The performance of the proposed clamping force controller is also verified experimentally using the HILS test bench. In order to implement the EWB in automotive industry, power consumption and reliability issues remain as future study.
